AI.motivation: Current motion editing methods lack full-scene context for consistent video editing, with I2V approaches missing context and V2V methods offering limited control over fine-grained object motion. There's a need for precise editing of both camera and object motions under complex movements.
AI.method: A track-conditioned V2V framework that conditions a video generation model on source video and paired 3D point tracks representing source and target motions. Uses 3D tracks (vs 2D) for explicit depth cues to resolve depth order and handle occlusions. Trained in two stages on synthetic and real data.
AI.result: Enables diverse motion edits including joint camera/object manipulation, motion transfer, and non-rigid deformation. Provides precise motion editing while preserving spatiotemporal coherence through 3D track correspondences.
AI.conclusion: The framework unlocks new creative potential in video editing by enabling precise joint editing of camera and object motion using 3D track conditioning, overcoming limitations of existing motion-controlled approaches.

title: Objects in Generated Videos Are Slower Than They Appear: Models Suffer Sub-Earth Gravity and Don't Know Galileo's Principle...for now
summary: Video generators are increasingly evaluated as potential world models, which requires them to encode and understand physical laws. We investigate their representation of a fundamental law: gravity. Out-of-the-box video generators consistently generate objects falling at an effectively slower acceleration. However, these physical tests are often confounded by ambiguous metric scale. We first investigate if observed physical errors are artifacts of these ambiguities (e.g., incorrect frame rate assumptions). We find that even temporal rescaling cannot correct the high-variance gravity artifacts. To rigorously isolate the underlying physical representation from these confounds, we introduce a unit-free, two-object protocol that tests the timing ratio $t_1^2/t_2^2 = h_1/h_2$, a relationship independent of $g$, focal length, and scale. This relative test reveals violations of Galileo's equivalence principle. We then demonstrate that this physical gap can be partially mitigated with targeted specialization. A lightweight low-rank adaptor fine-tuned on only 100 single-ball clips raises $g_{\mathrm{eff}}$ from $1.81\,\mathrm{m/s^2}$ to $6.43\,\mathrm{m/s^2}$ (reaching $65\%$ of terrestrial gravity). This specialist adaptor also generalizes zero-shot to two-ball drops and inclined planes, offering initial evidence that specific physical laws can be corrected with minimal data.

AI.tldr: Video generators fail to accurately represent gravity, showing objects falling at slower-than-real acceleration, but targeted fine-tuning with minimal data can partially correct this physical gap.
AI.motivation: To investigate whether video generators can serve as world models by testing their representation of fundamental physical laws like gravity, and to determine if observed physical errors are artifacts of ambiguous metric scale or genuine failures in physical understanding.
AI.method: 1) Test out-of-the-box video generators on gravity representation; 2) Investigate if errors are due to scale ambiguities (frame rate, focal length); 3) Introduce unit-free, two-object protocol testing timing ratio t₁²/t₂² = h₁/h₂ (independent of g, scale, focal length); 4) Use lightweight low-rank adaptor fine-tuned on only 100 single-ball clips to correct physical errors.
AI.result: Video generators consistently generate objects falling at slower acceleration (geff = 1.81 m/s² vs real 9.8 m/s²). Temporal rescaling cannot correct high-variance gravity artifacts. Unit-free protocol reveals violations of Galileo's equivalence principle. Fine-tuning raises geff to 6.43 m/s² (65% of terrestrial gravity). Specialist adaptor generalizes zero-shot to two-ball drops and inclined planes.
AI.conclusion: Video generators have significant gaps in representing fundamental physical laws like gravity, but targeted specialization with minimal data can partially correct these deficiencies, suggesting specific physical laws can be learned with small datasets.

title: Visual Sync: Multi-Camera Synchronization via Cross-View Object Motion
comment: Accepted to NeurIPS 2025. Project page: https://stevenlsw.github.io/visualsync/
summary: Today, people can easily record memorable moments, ranging from concerts, sports events, lectures, family gatherings, and birthday parties with multiple consumer cameras. However, synchronizing these cross-camera streams remains challenging. Existing methods assume controlled settings, specific targets, manual correction, or costly hardware. We present VisualSync, an optimization framework based on multi-view dynamics that aligns unposed, unsynchronized videos at millisecond accuracy. Our key insight is that any moving 3D point, when co-visible in two cameras, obeys epipolar constraints once properly synchronized. To exploit this, VisualSync leverages off-the-shelf 3D reconstruction, feature matching, and dense tracking to extract tracklets, relative poses, and cross-view correspondences. It then jointly minimizes the epipolar error to estimate each camera's time offset. Experiments on four diverse, challenging datasets show that VisualSync outperforms baseline methods, achieving an median synchronization error below 50 ms.

AI.tldr: VisualSync is an optimization framework that synchronizes unposed, unsynchronized videos from multiple consumer cameras with millisecond accuracy using multi-view dynamics and epipolar constraints.
AI.motivation: People can easily record events with multiple cameras, but synchronizing these cross-camera streams remains challenging. Existing methods require controlled settings, specific targets, manual correction, or expensive hardware.
AI.method: VisualSync uses multi-view dynamics optimization based on epipolar constraints. It leverages off-the-shelf 3D reconstruction, feature matching, and dense tracking to extract tracklets, relative poses, and cross-view correspondences, then jointly minimizes epipolar error to estimate each camera's time offset.
AI.result: Experiments on four diverse, challenging datasets show VisualSync outperforms baseline methods, achieving median synchronization error below 50 ms.
AI.conclusion: VisualSync provides an effective solution for synchronizing unposed, unsynchronized videos from consumer cameras with high accuracy, overcoming limitations of existing methods.

title: Data-Centric Visual Development for Self-Driving Labs
summary: Self-driving laboratories offer a promising path toward reducing the labor-intensive, time-consuming, and often irreproducible workflows in the biological sciences. Yet their stringent precision requirements demand highly robust models whose training relies on large amounts of annotated data. However, this kind of data is difficult to obtain in routine practice, especially negative samples. In this work, we focus on pipetting, the most critical and precision sensitive action in SDLs. To overcome the scarcity of training data, we build a hybrid pipeline that fuses real and virtual data generation. The real track adopts a human-in-the-loop scheme that couples automated acquisition with selective human verification to maximize accuracy with minimal effort. The virtual track augments the real data using reference-conditioned, prompt-guided image generation, which is further screened and validated for reliability. Together, these two tracks yield a class-balanced dataset that enables robust bubble detection training. On a held-out real test set, a model trained entirely on automatically acquired real images reaches 99.6% accuracy, and mixing real and generated data during training sustains 99.4% accuracy while reducing collection and review load. Our approach offers a scalable and cost-effective strategy for supplying visual feedback data to SDL workflows and provides a practical solution to data scarcity in rare event detection and broader vision tasks.

AI.tldr: Hybrid pipeline combining real human-verified data and virtual AI-generated data enables robust bubble detection for pipetting in self-driving labs, achieving 99.6% accuracy while reducing data collection burden.
AI.motivation: Self-driving labs need robust models requiring large annotated datasets, but negative samples (like pipetting bubbles) are rare and difficult to obtain in practice, creating a data scarcity problem for precision-critical tasks.
AI.method: Two-track approach: 1) Real track with human-in-the-loop scheme for automated acquisition with selective human verification; 2) Virtual track using reference-conditioned, prompt-guided image generation to augment real data, followed by screening and validation for reliability.
AI.result: Model trained on real-only data achieves 99.6% accuracy on held-out test set. Model trained on mixed real+generated data maintains 99.4% accuracy while reducing collection and review workload. Produces class-balanced dataset for robust bubble detection.
AI.conclusion: The hybrid pipeline provides scalable, cost-effective strategy for visual feedback data in SDL workflows, offering practical solution to data scarcity in rare event detection and broader vision tasks.

title: A Comprehensive Survey on Surgical Digital Twin
summary: With the accelerating availability of multimodal surgical data and real-time computation, Surgical Digital Twins (SDTs) have emerged as virtual counterparts that mirror, predict, and inform decisions across pre-, intra-, and postoperative care. Despite promising demonstrations, SDTs face persistent challenges: fusing heterogeneous imaging, kinematics, and physiology under strict latency budgets; balancing model fidelity with computational efficiency; ensuring robustness, interpretability, and calibrated uncertainty; and achieving interoperability, privacy, and regulatory compliance in clinical environments. This survey offers a critical, structured review of SDTs. We clarify terminology and scope, propose a taxonomy by purpose, model fidelity, and data sources, and synthesize state-of-the-art achievements in deformable registration and tracking, real-time simulation and co-simulation, AR/VR guidance, edge-cloud orchestration, and AI for scene understanding and prediction. We contrast non-robotic twins with robot-in-the-loop architectures for shared control and autonomy, and identify open problems in validation and benchmarking, safety assurance and human factors, lifecycle "digital thread" integration, and scalable data governance. We conclude with a research agenda toward trustworthy, standards-aligned SDTs that deliver measurable clinical benefit. By unifying vocabulary, organizing capabilities, and highlighting gaps, this work aims to guide SDT design and deployment and catalyze translation from laboratory prototypes to routine surgical care.

AI.tldr: This survey paper provides a comprehensive review of Surgical Digital Twins (SDTs) - virtual counterparts that mirror, predict, and inform surgical decisions across pre-, intra-, and postoperative care. It organizes the field, identifies challenges, and proposes a research agenda for clinical translation.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the accelerating availability of multimodal surgical data and real-time computation capabilities, while tackling persistent challenges in SDT development including heterogeneous data fusion, computational efficiency, robustness, interpretability, and clinical integration.
AI.method: The paper conducts a structured survey that clarifies terminology, proposes a taxonomy by purpose, model fidelity, and data sources, and synthesizes state-of-the-art achievements across multiple technical domains including deformable registration, real-time simulation, AR/VR guidance, edge-cloud orchestration, and AI for surgical scene understanding.
AI.result: The survey organizes the SDT field, contrasts non-robotic twins with robot-in-the-loop architectures, and identifies critical open problems in validation/benchmarking, safety assurance, human factors, lifecycle integration, and scalable data governance.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes with a research agenda toward trustworthy, standards-aligned SDTs that deliver measurable clinical benefit, aiming to guide SDT design and deployment and catalyze translation from laboratory prototypes to routine surgical care.

title: Foundation Models for Trajectory Planning in Autonomous Driving: A Review of Progress and Open Challenges
summary: The emergence of multi-modal foundation models has markedly transformed the technology for autonomous driving, shifting away from conventional and mostly hand-crafted design choices towards unified, foundation-model-based approaches, capable of directly inferring motion trajectories from raw sensory inputs. This new class of methods can also incorporate natural language as an additional modality, with Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models serving as a representative example. In this review, we provide a comprehensive examination of such methods through a unifying taxonomy to critically evaluate their architectural design choices, methodological strengths, and their inherent capabilities and limitations. Our survey covers 37 recently proposed approaches that span the landscape of trajectory planning with foundation models. Furthermore, we assess these approaches with respect to the openness of their source code and datasets, offering valuable information to practitioners and researchers. We provide an accompanying webpage that catalogs the methods based on our taxonomy, available at: https://github.com/fiveai/FMs-for-driving-trajectories

AI.tldr: A comprehensive review of 37 foundation model-based approaches for autonomous driving trajectory planning, analyzing their architectural designs, capabilities, limitations, and open-source availability.
AI.motivation: Multi-modal foundation models have revolutionized autonomous driving by enabling unified approaches that directly infer motion trajectories from raw sensory inputs, moving beyond traditional hand-crafted designs. The emergence of Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models incorporating natural language as an additional modality necessitates systematic evaluation.
AI.method: The authors conduct a comprehensive survey of 37 recently proposed approaches, developing a unifying taxonomy to critically evaluate architectural design choices, methodological strengths, capabilities, and limitations. They also assess the openness of source code and datasets.
AI.result: The review provides systematic analysis of foundation model-based trajectory planning methods, offering a taxonomy-based framework for evaluation. An accompanying webpage catalogs the methods according to the developed taxonomy.
AI.conclusion: Foundation models represent a transformative shift in autonomous driving trajectory planning, with VLA models enabling natural language integration. The survey provides valuable insights for practitioners and researchers through systematic evaluation and open-source assessment.

title: Learning from Watching: Scalable Extraction of Manipulation Trajectories from Human Videos
summary: Collecting high-quality data for training large-scale robotic models typically relies on real robot platforms, which is labor-intensive and costly, whether via teleoperation or scripted demonstrations. To scale data collection, many researchers have turned to leveraging human manipulation videos available online. However, current methods predominantly focus on hand detection or object pose estimation, failing to fully exploit the rich interaction cues embedded in these videos. In this work, we propose a novel approach that combines large foundation models for video understanding with point tracking techniques to extract dense trajectories of all task-relevant keypoints during manipulation. This enables more comprehensive utilization of Internet-scale human demonstration videos. Experimental results demonstrate that our method can accurately track keypoints throughout the entire manipulation process, paving the way for more scalable and data-efficient robot learning.

AI.tldr: A novel method combines foundation models and point tracking to extract dense keypoint trajectories from human manipulation videos for scalable robot learning.
AI.motivation: Real robot data collection is labor-intensive and costly. While online human manipulation videos are abundant, current methods fail to fully exploit the rich interaction cues in these videos, limiting their utility for robot learning.
AI.method: Proposes combining large foundation models for video understanding with point tracking techniques to extract dense trajectories of all task-relevant keypoints during manipulation from human demonstration videos.
AI.result: Experimental results show the method can accurately track keypoints throughout the entire manipulation process, enabling more comprehensive utilization of Internet-scale human demonstration videos.
AI.conclusion: The approach paves the way for more scalable and data-efficient robot learning by better leveraging abundant human demonstration videos through dense keypoint trajectory extraction.

title: A Survey on Improving Human Robot Collaboration through Vision-and-Language Navigation
summary: Vision-and-Language Navigation (VLN) is a multi-modal, cooperative task requiring agents to interpret human instructions, navigate 3D environments, and communicate effectively under ambiguity. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent VLN advancements in robotics and outlines promising directions to improve multi-robot coordination. Despite progress, current models struggle with bidirectional communication, ambiguity resolution, and collaborative decision-making in the multi-agent systems. We review approximately 200 relevant articles to provide an in-depth understanding of the current landscape. Through this survey, we aim to provide a thorough resource that inspires further research at the intersection of VLN and robotics. We advocate that the future VLN systems should support proactive clarification, real-time feedback, and contextual reasoning through advanced natural language understanding (NLU) techniques. Additionally, decentralized decision-making frameworks with dynamic role assignment are essential for scalable, efficient multi-robot collaboration. These innovations can significantly enhance human-robot interaction (HRI) and enable real-world deployment in domains such as healthcare, logistics, and disaster response.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive survey of Vision-and-Language Navigation (VLN) in robotics, reviewing ~200 papers to analyze current challenges and propose future directions for multi-robot coordination.
AI.motivation: VLN is a multi-modal task requiring agents to interpret instructions, navigate 3D environments, and communicate effectively, but current models struggle with bidirectional communication, ambiguity resolution, and collaborative decision-making in multi-agent systems.
AI.method: Comprehensive literature review of approximately 200 relevant articles to provide an in-depth understanding of the current VLN landscape in robotics.
AI.result: Identifies key limitations in current VLN systems and outlines promising research directions to improve multi-robot coordination.
AI.conclusion: Future VLN systems should support proactive clarification, real-time feedback, contextual reasoning through advanced NLU, and decentralized decision-making with dynamic role assignment to enhance HRI and enable real-world deployment in healthcare, logistics, and disaster response.

title: ICD-Net: Inertial Covariance Displacement Network for Drone Visual-Inertial SLAM
summary: Visual-inertial SLAM systems often exhibit suboptimal performance due to multiple confounding factors including imperfect sensor calibration, noisy measurements, rapid motion dynamics, low illumination, and the inherent limitations of traditional inertial navigation integration methods. These issues are particularly problematic in drone applications where robust and accurate state estimation is critical for safe autonomous operation. In this work, we present ICD-Net, a novel framework that enhances visual-inertial SLAM performance by learning to process raw inertial measurements and generating displacement estimates with associated uncertainty quantification. Rather than relying on analytical inertial sensor models that struggle with real-world sensor imperfections, our method directly extracts displacement maps from sensor data while simultaneously predicting measurement covariances that reflect estimation confidence. We integrate ICD-Net outputs as additional residual constraints into the VINS-Fusion optimization framework, where the predicted uncertainties appropriately weight the neural network contributions relative to traditional visual and inertial terms. The learned displacement constraints provide complementary information that compensates for various error sources in the SLAM pipeline. Our approach can be used under both normal operating conditions and in situations of camera inconsistency or visual degradation. Experimental evaluation on challenging high-speed drone sequences demonstrated that our approach significantly improved trajectory estimation accuracy compared to standard VINS-Fusion, with more than 38% improvement in mean APE and uncertainty estimates proving crucial for maintaining system robustness. Our method shows that neural network enhancement can effectively address multiple sources of SLAM degradation while maintaining real-time performance requirements.

AI.tldr: ICD-Net enhances visual-inertial SLAM by learning displacement estimates from raw inertial data with uncertainty quantification, integrated into VINS-Fusion to improve drone trajectory accuracy by over 38%.
AI.motivation: Visual-inertial SLAM systems suffer from multiple issues: imperfect sensor calibration, noisy measurements, rapid motion, low light, and limitations of traditional inertial integration. These problems are especially critical for drone applications requiring robust state estimation for safe autonomous operation.
AI.method: ICD-Net learns to process raw inertial measurements to generate displacement estimates with uncertainty quantification. Instead of using analytical sensor models, it directly extracts displacement maps while predicting measurement covariances. These outputs are integrated as additional residual constraints into VINS-Fusion, where predicted uncertainties appropriately weight neural network contributions relative to traditional visual and inertial terms.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation on challenging high-speed drone sequences showed significant improvement in trajectory estimation accuracy compared to standard VINS-Fusion, with more than 38% improvement in mean APE. Uncertainty estimates proved crucial for maintaining system robustness, and the method works under both normal conditions and during camera inconsistency/visual degradation.
AI.conclusion: Neural network enhancement can effectively address multiple sources of SLAM degradation while maintaining real-time performance requirements. The learned displacement constraints provide complementary information that compensates for various error sources in the SLAM pipeline.

title: VISTAv2: World Imagination for Indoor Vision-and-Language Navigation
summary: Vision-and-Language Navigation (VLN) requires agents to follow language instructions while acting in continuous real-world spaces. Prior image imagination based VLN work shows benefits for discrete panoramas but lacks online, action-conditioned predictions and does not produce explicit planning values; moreover, many methods replace the planner with long-horizon objectives that are brittle and slow. To bridge this gap, we propose VISTAv2, a generative world model that rolls out egocentric future views conditioned on past observations, candidate action sequences, and instructions, and projects them into an online value map for planning. Unlike prior approaches, VISTAv2 does not replace the planner. The online value map is fused at score level with the base objective, providing reachability and risk-aware guidance. Concretely, we employ an action-aware Conditional Diffusion Transformer video predictor to synthesize short-horizon futures, align them with the natural language instruction via a vision-language scorer, and fuse multiple rollouts in a differentiable imagination-to-value head to output an imagined egocentric value map. For efficiency, rollouts occur in VAE latent space with a distilled sampler and sparse decoding, enabling inference on a single consumer GPU. Evaluated on MP3D and RoboTHOR, VISTAv2 improves over strong baselines, and ablations show that action-conditioned imagination, instruction-guided value fusion, and the online value-map planner are all critical, suggesting that VISTAv2 offers a practical and interpretable route to robust VLN.

AI.tldr: VISTAv2 is a generative world model for Vision-and-Language Navigation that synthesizes action-conditioned future views, aligns them with instructions, and creates online value maps for robust planning.
AI.motivation: Prior VLN methods lack online, action-conditioned predictions and explicit planning values, often replacing planners with brittle long-horizon objectives that are slow and unreliable.
AI.method: Uses Conditional Diffusion Transformer video predictor to synthesize short-horizon futures, aligns them with instructions via vision-language scorer, fuses multiple rollouts in differentiable imagination-to-value head to output imagined egocentric value maps.
AI.result: Improves over strong baselines on MP3D and RoboTHOR benchmarks; ablations show action-conditioned imagination, instruction-guided value fusion, and online value-map planner are all critical components.
AI.conclusion: VISTAv2 offers a practical and interpretable route to robust VLN by providing reachability and risk-aware guidance through online value maps without replacing the planner.

title: Coarse-to-Fine Non-Rigid Registration for Side-Scan Sonar Mosaicking
summary: Side-scan sonar mosaicking plays a crucial role in large-scale seabed mapping but is challenged by complex non-linear, spatially varying distortions due to diverse sonar acquisition conditions. Existing rigid or affine registration methods fail to model such complex deformations, whereas traditional non-rigid techniques tend to overfit and lack robustness in sparse-texture sonar data. To address these challenges, we propose a coarse-to-fine hierarchical non-rigid registration framework tailored for large-scale side-scan sonar images. Our method begins with a global Thin Plate Spline initialization from sparse correspondences, followed by superpixel-guided segmentation that partitions the image into structurally consistent patches preserving terrain integrity. Each patch is then refined by a pretrained SynthMorph network in an unsupervised manner, enabling dense and flexible alignment without task-specific training. Finally, a fusion strategy integrates both global and local deformations into a smooth, unified deformation field. Extensive quantitative and visual evaluations demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art rigid, classical non-rigid, and learning-based methods in accuracy, structural consistency, and deformation smoothness on the challenging sonar dataset.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical non-rigid registration framework for side-scan sonar mosaicking that combines global TPS initialization with superpixel-guided segmentation and SynthMorph refinement for accurate, smooth deformation fields.
AI.motivation: Side-scan sonar mosaicking faces challenges with complex non-linear, spatially varying distortions from diverse acquisition conditions. Existing rigid/affine methods can't model complex deformations, while traditional non-rigid techniques overfit and lack robustness in sparse-texture sonar data.
AI.method: Coarse-to-fine hierarchical framework: 1) Global Thin Plate Spline initialization from sparse correspondences, 2) Superpixel-guided segmentation into structurally consistent patches preserving terrain integrity, 3) Patch refinement using pretrained SynthMorph network in unsupervised manner, 4) Fusion strategy integrating global and local deformations into smooth unified deformation field.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations show the approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art rigid, classical non-rigid, and learning-based methods in accuracy, structural consistency, and deformation smoothness on challenging sonar datasets.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hierarchical non-rigid registration framework effectively addresses complex distortions in side-scan sonar mosaicking, providing superior performance through its coarse-to-fine approach that balances flexibility with robustness.

title: Bootstrap Dynamic-Aware 3D Visual Representation for Scalable Robot Learning
summary: Despite strong results on recognition and segmentation, current 3D visual pre-training methods often underperform on robotic manipulation. We attribute this gap to two factors: the lack of state-action-state dynamics modeling and the unnecessary redundancy of explicit geometric reconstruction. We introduce AFRO, a self-supervised framework that learns dynamics-aware 3D representations without action or reconstruction supervision. AFRO casts state prediction as a generative diffusion process and jointly models forward and inverse dynamics in a shared latent space to capture causal transition structure. To prevent feature leakage in action learning, we employ feature differencing and inverse-consistency supervision, improving the quality and stability of visual features. When combined with Diffusion Policy, AFRO substantially increases manipulation success rates across 16 simulated and 4 real-world tasks, outperforming existing pre-training approaches. The framework also scales favorably with data volume and task complexity. Qualitative visualizations indicate that AFRO learns semantically rich, discriminative features, offering an effective pre-training solution for 3D representation learning in robotics. Project page: https://kolakivy.github.io/AFRO/

AI.tldr: AFRO is a self-supervised 3D representation learning framework for robotics that learns dynamics-aware features without action or reconstruction supervision, improving manipulation performance.
AI.motivation: Current 3D visual pre-training methods underperform on robotic manipulation due to lack of state-action-state dynamics modeling and unnecessary redundancy of explicit geometric reconstruction.
AI.method: AFRO casts state prediction as a generative diffusion process, jointly models forward and inverse dynamics in shared latent space, uses feature differencing and inverse-consistency supervision to prevent feature leakage.
AI.result: AFRO substantially increases manipulation success rates across 16 simulated and 4 real-world tasks, outperforming existing pre-training approaches, and scales favorably with data volume and task complexity.
AI.conclusion: AFRO learns semantically rich, discriminative features and offers an effective pre-training solution for 3D representation learning in robotics.

title: Arcadia: Toward a Full-Lifecycle Framework for Embodied Lifelong Learning
summary: We contend that embodied learning is fundamentally a lifecycle problem rather than a single-stage optimization. Systems that optimize only one link (data collection, simulation, learning, or deployment) rarely sustain improvement or generalize beyond narrow settings. We introduce Arcadia, a closed-loop framework that operationalizes embodied lifelong learning by tightly coupling four stages: (1) Self-evolving exploration and grounding for autonomous data acquisition in physical environments, (2) Generative scene reconstruction and augmentation for realistic and extensible scene creation, (3) a Shared embodied representation architecture that unifies navigation and manipulation within a single multimodal backbone, and (4) Sim-from-real evaluation and evolution that closes the feedback loop through simulation-based adaptation. This coupling is non-decomposable: removing any stage breaks the improvement loop and reverts to one-shot training. Arcadia delivers consistent gains on navigation and manipulation benchmarks and transfers robustly to physical robots, indicating that a tightly coupled lifecycle: continuous real-world data acquisition, generative simulation update, and shared-representation learning, supports lifelong improvement and end-to-end generalization. We release standardized interfaces enabling reproducible evaluation and cross-model comparison in reusable environments, positioning Arcadia as a scalable foundation for general-purpose embodied agents.

AI.tldr: Arcadia is a closed-loop framework for embodied lifelong learning that couples four stages: autonomous data collection, generative scene creation, shared multimodal representation, and simulation-based adaptation, enabling continuous improvement and generalization in physical robots.
AI.motivation: Current embodied learning systems optimize only single stages (data, simulation, learning, or deployment), leading to unsustainable improvement and poor generalization. The authors argue that embodied learning is fundamentally a lifecycle problem requiring tight coupling of all stages for lifelong learning.
AI.method: Arcadia introduces a closed-loop framework with four tightly coupled stages: (1) Self-evolving exploration for autonomous physical data acquisition, (2) Generative scene reconstruction/augmentation for realistic scene creation, (3) Shared embodied representation unifying navigation/manipulation in a single multimodal backbone, and (4) Sim-from-real evaluation/evolution closing the feedback loop through simulation-based adaptation.
AI.result: Arcadia delivers consistent gains on navigation and manipulation benchmarks and transfers robustly to physical robots. The framework demonstrates that continuous real-world data acquisition, generative simulation updates, and shared-representation learning support lifelong improvement and end-to-end generalization.
AI.conclusion: Embodied learning requires a tightly coupled lifecycle approach rather than single-stage optimization. Arcadia provides a scalable foundation for general-purpose embodied agents through its non-decomposable closed-loop framework, with standardized interfaces enabling reproducible evaluation and cross-model comparison.

title: HMARK: Radioactive Multi-Bit Semantic-Latent Watermarking for Diffusion Models
summary: Modern generative diffusion models rely on vast training datasets, often including images with uncertain ownership or usage rights. Radioactive watermarks -- marks that transfer to a model's outputs -- can help detect when such unauthorized data has been used for training. Moreover, aside from being radioactive, an effective watermark for protecting images from unauthorized training also needs to meet other existing requirements, such as imperceptibility, robustness, and multi-bit capacity. To overcome these challenges, we propose HMARK, a novel multi-bit watermarking scheme, which encodes ownership information as secret bits in the semantic-latent space (h-space) for image diffusion models. By leveraging the interpretability and semantic significance of h-space, ensuring that watermark signals correspond to meaningful semantic attributes, the watermarks embedded by HMARK exhibit radioactivity, robustness to distortions, and minimal impact on perceptual quality. Experimental results demonstrate that HMARK achieves 98.57% watermark detection accuracy, 95.07% bit-level recovery accuracy, 100% recall rate, and 1.0 AUC on images produced by the downstream adversarial model finetuned with LoRA on watermarked data across various types of distortions.

AI.tldr: HMARK is a multi-bit watermarking scheme for diffusion models that embeds ownership information in the semantic-latent space (h-space), achieving radioactive transfer to model outputs while maintaining imperceptibility, robustness, and high detection accuracy.
AI.motivation: Modern generative diffusion models often use training data with uncertain ownership rights. There's a need for effective watermarks that can detect unauthorized training data usage while meeting requirements like imperceptibility, robustness, and multi-bit capacity.
AI.method: HMARK encodes ownership information as secret bits in the semantic-latent space (h-space) of image diffusion models. By leveraging h-space's interpretability and semantic significance, watermark signals correspond to meaningful semantic attributes, ensuring radioactivity and robustness.
AI.result: HMARK achieves 98.57% watermark detection accuracy, 95.07% bit-level recovery accuracy, 100% recall rate, and 1.0 AUC on images produced by adversarial models finetuned with LoRA on watermarked data across various distortions.
AI.conclusion: HMARK provides an effective solution for protecting images from unauthorized training in diffusion models by combining radioactive properties with imperceptibility, robustness, and multi-bit capacity through semantic-latent space encoding.

title: MoLT: Mixture of Layer-Wise Tokens for Efficient Audio-Visual Learning
summary: In this paper, we propose Mixture of Layer-Wise Tokens (MoLT), a parameter- and memory-efficient adaptation framework for audio-visual learning. The key idea of MoLT is to replace conventional, computationally heavy sequential adaptation at every transformer layer with a parallel, lightweight scheme that extracts and fuses layer-wise tokens only from the late layers. We adopt two types of adapters to distill modality-specific information and cross-modal interaction into compact latent tokens in a layer-wise manner. A token fusion module then dynamically fuses these layer-wise tokens by taking into account their relative significance. To prevent the redundancy of latent tokens, we apply an orthogonality regularization between latent tokens during training. Through the systematic analysis of the position of adaptation in the pre-trained transformers, we extract latent tokens only from the late layers of the transformers. This strategic adaptation approach avoids error propagation from the volatile early-layer features, thereby maximizing the adaptation performance while maintaining parameter and memory efficiency. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that MoLT outperforms existing methods on diverse audio-visual benchmarks, including Audio-Visual Question Answering, Audio-Visual Segmentation, and Audio-Visual Event Localization.

AI.tldr: MoLT is a parameter-efficient adaptation framework for audio-visual learning that uses parallel layer-wise token extraction and fusion from late transformer layers instead of sequential adaptation.
AI.motivation: To address the computational inefficiency of conventional sequential adaptation methods in audio-visual learning that require heavy computation at every transformer layer.
AI.method: Uses two types of adapters to distill modality-specific and cross-modal information into compact latent tokens layer-wise, with token fusion module and orthogonality regularization to prevent redundancy. Extracts tokens only from late transformer layers.
AI.result: Outperforms existing methods on diverse audio-visual benchmarks including Audio-Visual Question Answering, Audio-Visual Segmentation, and Audio-Visual Event Localization.
AI.conclusion: MoLT provides a parameter- and memory-efficient adaptation framework that avoids error propagation from early-layer features while maintaining strong performance across multiple audio-visual tasks.

title: Art2Music: Generating Music for Art Images with Multi-modal Feeling Alignment
summary: With the rise of AI-generated content (AIGC), generating perceptually natural and feeling-aligned music from multimodal inputs has become a central challenge. Existing approaches often rely on explicit emotion labels that require costly annotation, underscoring the need for more flexible feeling-aligned methods. To support multimodal music generation, we construct ArtiCaps, a pseudo feeling-aligned image-music-text dataset created by semantically matching descriptions from ArtEmis and MusicCaps. We further propose Art2Music, a lightweight cross-modal framework that synthesizes music from artistic images and user comments. In the first stage, images and text are encoded with OpenCLIP and fused using a gated residual module; the fused representation is decoded by a bidirectional LSTM into Mel-spectrograms with a frequency-weighted L1 loss to enhance high-frequency fidelity. In the second stage, a fine-tuned HiFi-GAN vocoder reconstructs high-quality audio waveforms. Experiments on ArtiCaps show clear improvements in Mel-Cepstral Distortion, Frechet Audio Distance, Log-Spectral Distance, and cosine similarity. A small LLM-based rating study further verifies consistent cross-modal feeling alignment and offers interpretable explanations of matches and mismatches across modalities. These results demonstrate improved perceptual naturalness, spectral fidelity, and semantic consistency. Art2Music also maintains robust performance with only 50k training samples, providing a scalable solution for feeling-aligned creative audio generation in interactive art, personalized soundscapes, and digital art exhibitions.

AI.tldr: Art2Music: A lightweight cross-modal framework that generates feeling-aligned music from artistic images and user comments, using a two-stage approach with improved perceptual naturalness and semantic consistency.
AI.motivation: Existing AI-generated music methods rely on costly explicit emotion labels, creating need for more flexible feeling-aligned approaches that can work with multimodal inputs like images and text.
AI.method: Two-stage framework: 1) Image and text encoded with OpenCLIP, fused via gated residual module, decoded by bidirectional LSTM into Mel-spectrograms with frequency-weighted L1 loss; 2) Fine-tuned HiFi-GAN vocoder reconstructs high-quality audio waveforms. Dataset: ArtiCaps (pseudo feeling-aligned image-music-text).
AI.result: Clear improvements in Mel-Cepstral Distortion, Frechet Audio Distance, Log-Spectral Distance, and cosine similarity. LLM-based rating study verifies consistent cross-modal feeling alignment with interpretable explanations.
AI.conclusion: Art2Music demonstrates improved perceptual naturalness, spectral fidelity, and semantic consistency while maintaining robust performance with only 50k training samples, providing scalable solution for feeling-aligned creative audio generation.

title: Ternary-Input Binary-Weight CNN Accelerator Design for Miniature Object Classification System with Query-Driven Spatial DVS
summary: Miniature imaging systems are essential for space-constrained applications but are limited by memory and power constraints. While machine learning can reduce data size by extracting key features, its high energy demands often exceed the capacity of small batteries. This paper presents a CNN hardware accelerator optimized for object classification in miniature imaging systems. It processes data from a spatial Dynamic Vision Sensor (DVS), reconfigurable to a temporal DVS via pixel sharing, minimizing sensor area. By using ternary DVS outputs and a ternary-input, binary-weight neural network, the design reduces computation and memory needs. Fabricated in 28 nm CMOS, the accelerator cuts data size by 81% and MAC operations by 27%. It achieves 440 ms inference time at just 1.6 mW power consumption, improving the Figure-of-Merit (FoM) by 7.3x over prior CNN accelerators for miniature systems.

AI.tldr: A CNN hardware accelerator for miniature imaging systems that processes DVS sensor data using ternary inputs and binary weights, achieving 81% data reduction and 1.6 mW power consumption.
AI.motivation: Miniature imaging systems face memory and power constraints, and while machine learning can reduce data size, its high energy demands exceed small battery capacities. There's a need for efficient hardware accelerators that can perform object classification within these strict constraints.
AI.method: The paper presents a CNN hardware accelerator that processes data from a spatial Dynamic Vision Sensor (DVS), which can be reconfigured to temporal DVS via pixel sharing to minimize sensor area. The design uses ternary DVS outputs and implements a ternary-input, binary-weight neural network to reduce computation and memory requirements.
AI.result: Fabricated in 28 nm CMOS, the accelerator achieves 81% data size reduction and 27% reduction in MAC operations. It delivers 440 ms inference time with only 1.6 mW power consumption, improving the Figure-of-Merit (FoM) by 7.3x compared to prior CNN accelerators for miniature systems.
AI.conclusion: The proposed CNN hardware accelerator successfully addresses the power and memory constraints of miniature imaging systems through efficient sensor design and neural network optimization, making it suitable for space-constrained applications with limited battery capacity.

title: TIE: A Training-Inversion-Exclusion Framework for Visually Interpretable and Uncertainty-Guided Out-of-Distribution Detection
summary: Deep neural networks often struggle to recognize when an input lies outside their training experience, leading to unreliable and overconfident predictions. Building dependable machine learning systems therefore requires methods that can both estimate predictive \textit{uncertainty} and detect \textit{out-of-distribution (OOD)} samples in a unified manner. In this paper, we propose \textbf{TIE: a Training--Inversion--Exclusion} framework for visually interpretable and uncertainty-guided anomaly detection that jointly addresses these challenges through iterative refinement. TIE extends a standard $n$-class classifier to an $(n+1)$-class model by introducing a garbage class initialized with Gaussian noise to represent outlier inputs. Within each epoch, TIE performs a closed-loop process of \textit{training, inversion, and exclusion}, where highly uncertain inverted samples reconstructed from the just-trained classifier are excluded into the garbage class. Over successive iterations, the inverted samples transition from noisy artifacts into visually coherent class prototypes, providing transparent insight into how the model organizes its learned manifolds. During inference, TIE rejects OOD inputs by either directly mapping them to the garbage class or producing low-confidence, uncertain misclassifications within the in-distribution classes that are easily separable, all without relying on external OOD datasets. A comprehensive threshold-based evaluation using multiple OOD metrics and performance measures such as \textit{AUROC}, \textit{AUPR}, and \textit{FPR@95\%TPR} demonstrates that TIE offers a unified and interpretable framework for robust anomaly detection and calibrated uncertainty estimation (UE) achieving near-perfect OOD detection with \textbf{\(\!\approx\!\) 0 FPR@95\%TPR} when trained on MNIST or FashionMNIST and tested against diverse unseen datasets.

AI.tldr: TIE is a unified framework for uncertainty estimation and out-of-distribution detection that extends classifiers with a garbage class and uses iterative training-inversion-exclusion to create visually interpretable anomaly detection.
AI.motivation: Deep neural networks often fail to recognize out-of-distribution inputs and produce overconfident predictions, creating unreliable systems. There's a need for unified methods that can both estimate uncertainty and detect OOD samples.
AI.method: TIE extends n-class classifiers to (n+1)-class models by adding a garbage class initialized with Gaussian noise. It performs iterative training-inversion-exclusion: training the classifier, inverting highly uncertain samples from the trained model, and excluding them into the garbage class. This creates visually coherent class prototypes over time.
AI.result: TIE achieves near-perfect OOD detection with approximately 0 FPR@95%TPR when trained on MNIST or FashionMNIST and tested against diverse unseen datasets, as measured by AUROC, AUPR, and FPR@95%TPR metrics.
AI.conclusion: TIE provides a unified, interpretable framework for robust anomaly detection and calibrated uncertainty estimation that doesn't rely on external OOD datasets, offering transparent insight into how models organize learned manifolds.

title: RealAppliance: Let High-fidelity Appliance Assets Controllable and Workable as Aligned Real Manuals
summary: Existing appliance assets suffer from poor rendering, incomplete mechanisms, and misalignment with manuals, leading to simulation-reality gaps that hinder appliance manipulation development. In this work, we introduce the RealAppliance dataset, comprising 100 high-fidelity appliances with complete physical, electronic mechanisms, and program logic aligned with their manuals. Based on these assets, we propose the RealAppliance-Bench benchmark, which evaluates multimodal large language models and embodied manipulation planning models across key tasks in appliance manipulation planning: manual page retrieval, appliance part grounding, open-loop manipulation planning, and closed-loop planning adjustment. Our analysis of model performances on RealAppliance-Bench provides insights for advancing appliance manipulation research

AI.tldr: RealAppliance dataset with 100 high-fidelity appliances and RealAppliance-Bench benchmark for evaluating multimodal LLMs and embodied manipulation models on appliance manipulation tasks.
AI.motivation: Existing appliance assets have poor rendering, incomplete mechanisms, and misalignment with manuals, creating simulation-reality gaps that hinder appliance manipulation development.
AI.method: Introduce RealAppliance dataset with 100 high-fidelity appliances featuring complete physical, electronic mechanisms, and program logic aligned with manuals. Create RealAppliance-Bench benchmark to evaluate multimodal LLMs and embodied manipulation planning models.
AI.result: Benchmark evaluates models across four key tasks: manual page retrieval, appliance part grounding, open-loop manipulation planning, and closed-loop planning adjustment.
AI.conclusion: Analysis of model performances on RealAppliance-Bench provides insights for advancing appliance manipulation research.

title: MILE: A Mechanically Isomorphic Exoskeleton Data Collection System with Fingertip Visuotactile Sensing for Dexterous Manipulation
summary: Imitation learning provides a promising approach to dexterous hand manipulation, but its effectiveness is limited by the lack of large-scale, high-fidelity data. Existing data-collection pipelines suffer from inaccurate motion retargeting, low data-collection efficiency, and missing high-resolution fingertip tactile sensing. We address this gap with MILE, a mechanically isomorphic teleoperation and data-collection system co-designed from human hand to exoskeleton to robotic hand. The exoskeleton is anthropometrically derived from the human hand, and the robotic hand preserves one-to-one joint-position isomorphism, eliminating nonlinear retargeting and enabling precise, natural control. The exoskeleton achieves a multi-joint mean absolute angular error below one degree, while the robotic hand integrates compact fingertip visuotactile modules that provide high-resolution tactile observations. Built on this retargeting-free interface, we teleoperate complex, contact-rich in-hand manipulation and efficiently collect a multimodal dataset comprising high-resolution fingertip visuotactile signals, RGB-D images, and joint positions. The teleoperation pipeline achieves a mean success rate improvement of 64%. Incorporating fingertip tactile observations further increases the success rate by an average of 25% over the vision-only baseline, validating the fidelity and utility of the dataset. Further details are available at: https://sites.google.com/view/mile-system.

AI.tldr: MILE is a teleoperation system for dexterous hand manipulation that eliminates motion retargeting through mechanical isomorphism between human hand, exoskeleton, and robotic hand, enabling high-fidelity data collection with fingertip tactile sensing.
AI.motivation: Imitation learning for dexterous hand manipulation lacks large-scale, high-fidelity data due to inaccurate motion retargeting, low data-collection efficiency, and missing high-resolution fingertip tactile sensing in existing systems.
AI.method: Developed MILE system with mechanically isomorphic design: anthropometric exoskeleton derived from human hand + robotic hand with one-to-one joint-position isomorphism, eliminating nonlinear retargeting. Integrated compact fingertip visuotactile modules for high-resolution tactile observations.
AI.result: Exoskeleton achieved <1° mean absolute angular error; teleoperation pipeline improved success rate by 64%; fingertip tactile observations increased success rate by 25% over vision-only baseline; collected multimodal dataset with visuotactile signals, RGB-D images, and joint positions.
AI.conclusion: MILE's retargeting-free teleoperation system enables efficient collection of high-fidelity multimodal data for dexterous manipulation, demonstrating the value of mechanical isomorphism and fingertip tactile sensing for improving imitation learning performance.

title: MedCondDiff: Lightweight, Robust, Semantically Guided Diffusion for Medical Image Segmentation
summary: We introduce MedCondDiff, a diffusion-based framework for multi-organ medical image segmentation that is efficient and anatomically grounded. The model conditions the denoising process on semantic priors extracted by a Pyramid Vision Transformer (PVT) backbone, yielding a semantically guided and lightweight diffusion architecture. This design improves robustness while reducing both inference time and VRAM usage compared to conventional diffusion models. Experiments on multi-organ, multi-modality datasets demonstrate that MedCondDiff delivers competitive performance across anatomical regions and imaging modalities, underscoring the potential of semantically guided diffusion models as an effective class of architectures for medical imaging tasks.

AI.tldr: MedCondDiff is a diffusion-based framework for multi-organ medical image segmentation that uses semantic priors from PVT backbone to guide denoising, making it efficient and anatomically grounded.
AI.motivation: To create a more efficient and robust medical image segmentation model that addresses the computational limitations of conventional diffusion models while maintaining anatomical accuracy across multiple organs and imaging modalities.
AI.method: Uses a diffusion-based framework conditioned on semantic priors extracted by a Pyramid Vision Transformer (PVT) backbone. The semantic guidance directs the denoising process, creating a lightweight architecture that reduces VRAM usage and inference time.
AI.result: The model demonstrates competitive performance across multi-organ, multi-modality datasets, showing improved robustness while reducing both inference time and VRAM usage compared to conventional diffusion models.
AI.conclusion: Semantically guided diffusion models represent an effective class of architectures for medical imaging tasks, offering a promising balance between performance and computational efficiency for multi-organ segmentation.

title: Time-Series at the Edge: Tiny Separable CNNs for Wearable Gait Detection and Optimal Sensor Placement
summary: We study on-device time-series analysis for gait detection in Parkinson's disease (PD) from short windows of triaxial acceleration, targeting resource-constrained wearables and edge nodes. We compare magnitude thresholding to three 1D CNNs for time-series analysis: a literature baseline (separable convolutions) and two ultra-light models - one purely separable and one with residual connections. Using the BioStampRC21 dataset, 2 s windows at 30 Hz, and subject-independent leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) validation on 16 PwPD with chest-worn IMUs, our residual separable model (Model 2, 533 params) attains PR-AUC = 94.5%, F1 = 91.2%, MCC = 89.4%, matching or surpassing the baseline (5,552 params; PR-AUC = 93.7%, F1 = 90.5%, MCC = 88.5%) with approximately 10x fewer parameters. The smallest model (Model 1, 305 params) reaches PR-AUC = 94.0%, F1 = 91.0%, MCC = 89.1%. Thresholding obtains high recall (89.0%) but low precision (76.5%), yielding many false positives and high inter-subject variance. Sensor-position analysis (train-on-all) shows chest and thighs are most reliable; forearms degrade precision/recall due to non-gait arm motion; naive fusion of all sites does not outperform the best single site. Both compact CNNs execute within tight memory/latency budgets on STM32-class MCUs (sub-10 ms on low-power boards), enabling on-sensor gating of transmission/storage. Overall, ultra-light separable CNNs provide a superior accuracy-efficiency-generalization trade-off to fixed thresholds for wearable PD gait detection and underscore the value of tailored time-series models for edge deployment.

AI.tldr: Ultra-light 1D CNNs (305-533 parameters) outperform magnitude thresholding for Parkinson's gait detection on resource-constrained wearables, achieving ~94% PR-AUC with 10x fewer parameters than baseline models.
AI.motivation: Enable accurate gait detection for Parkinson's disease monitoring on resource-constrained wearable devices and edge nodes, overcoming limitations of simple thresholding methods that produce many false positives and high inter-subject variance.
AI.method: Compared magnitude thresholding to three 1D CNN architectures: literature baseline (separable convolutions, 5,552 params) and two ultra-light models (purely separable and residual separable). Used BioStampRC21 dataset with 2-second windows at 30Hz, subject-independent LOSO validation on 16 PD patients with chest-worn IMUs. Analyzed sensor positions (chest, thighs, forearms) and naive fusion.
AI.result: Residual separable model (533 params) achieved PR-AUC=94.5%, F1=91.2%, MCC=89.4%, matching/surpassing baseline (5,552 params). Smallest model (305 params) reached PR-AUC=94.0%. Thresholding had high recall (89.0%) but low precision (76.5%). Chest and thighs most reliable; forearms degraded due to non-gait arm motion. CNNs executed within tight memory/latency budgets on STM32-class MCUs (sub-10ms).
AI.conclusion: Ultra-light separable CNNs provide superior accuracy-efficiency-generalization trade-off for wearable PD gait detection compared to fixed thresholds, enabling on-sensor gating of transmission/storage and demonstrating the value of tailored time-series models for edge deployment.

title: SelfAI: Building a Self-Training AI System with LLM Agents
summary: Recent work on autonomous scientific discovery has leveraged LLM-based agents to integrate problem specification, experiment planning, and execution into end-to-end systems. However, these frameworks are often confined to narrow application domains, offer limited real-time interaction with researchers, and lack principled mechanisms for determining when to halt exploration, resulting in inefficiencies, reproducibility challenges, and under-utilized human expertise. To address these gaps, we propose \textit{SelfAI}, a general multi-agent platform that combines a User Agent for translating high-level research objectives into standardized experimental configurations, a Cognitive Agent powered by LLMs with optimal stopping criteria to iteratively refine hyperparameter searches, and an Experiment Manager responsible for orchestrating parallel, fault-tolerant training workflows across heterogeneous hardware while maintaining a structured knowledge base for continuous feedback. We further introduce two novel evaluation metrics, Score and $\text{AUP}_D$, to quantify discovery efficiency and search diversity. Across regression, NLP, computer vision, scientific computing, medical imaging, and drug discovery benchmarks, SelfAI consistently achieves strong performance and reduces redundant trials compared to classical Bayesian optimization and LLM-based baselines, while enabling seamless interaction with human researchers.

AI.tldr: SelfAI is a multi-agent platform for autonomous scientific discovery that integrates user interaction, intelligent search with optimal stopping, and experiment management, outperforming existing methods across diverse domains.
AI.motivation: Current autonomous discovery systems are limited by narrow application domains, lack real-time researcher interaction, and have no principled stopping mechanisms, leading to inefficiencies and under-utilized human expertise.
AI.method: SelfAI uses three agents: User Agent translates research objectives into experimental configurations; Cognitive Agent with LLMs and optimal stopping criteria refines hyperparameter searches; Experiment Manager orchestrates parallel, fault-tolerant training workflows across heterogeneous hardware with structured knowledge base.
AI.result: SelfAI achieves strong performance across regression, NLP, computer vision, scientific computing, medical imaging, and drug discovery benchmarks, reduces redundant trials compared to Bayesian optimization and LLM baselines, and enables seamless human interaction.
AI.conclusion: SelfAI addresses key limitations in autonomous scientific discovery by providing a general multi-agent platform with principled stopping mechanisms, efficient search, and effective human-AI collaboration across diverse domains.

title: Fast, Robust, Permutation-and-Sign Invariant SO(3) Pattern Alignment
summary:
We address the correspondence-free alignment of two rotation sets on \(SO(3)\), a core task in calibration and registration that is often impeded by missing time alignment, outliers, and unknown axis conventions. Our key idea is to decompose each rotation into its \emph{Transformed Basis Vectors} (TBVs)-three unit vectors on \(S^2\)-and align the resulting spherical point sets per axis using fast, robust matchers (SPMC, FRS, and a hybrid). To handle axis relabels and sign flips, we introduce a \emph{Permutation-and-Sign Invariant} (PASI) wrapper that enumerates the 24 proper signed permutations, scores them via summed correlations, and fuses the per-axis estimates into a single rotation by projection/Karcher mean. The overall complexity remains linear in the number of rotations (\(\mathcal{O}(n)\)), contrasting with \(\mathcal{O}(N_r^3\log N_r)\) for spherical/\(SO(3)\) correlation. Experiments on EuRoC Machine Hall simulations
  (axis-consistent) and the ETH Hand-Eye benchmark (\texttt{robot\_arm\_real})
  (axis-ambiguous) show that our methods are accurate, 6-60x faster than traditional methods, and robust under extreme outlier ratios (up to 90\%), all without correspondence search.

AI.tldr: A correspondence-free method for aligning rotation sets on SO(3) using Transformed Basis Vectors decomposition and permutation-and-sign invariant matching, achieving linear complexity and robustness to outliers.
AI.motivation: Rotation set alignment is crucial for calibration and registration but faces challenges from missing time alignment, outliers, unknown axis conventions, and axis relabeling/sign flips. Traditional methods have high computational complexity (O(N_r^3 log N_r)) and require correspondence search.
AI.method: Decompose each rotation into three Transformed Basis Vectors (unit vectors on S^2), align resulting spherical point sets per axis using robust matchers (SPMC, FRS, hybrid). Handle axis relabels/sign flips with Permutation-and-Sign Invariant wrapper that enumerates 24 proper signed permutations, scores via summed correlations, and fuses per-axis estimates via projection/Karcher mean.
AI.result: Methods are accurate, 6-60x faster than traditional methods, robust under extreme outlier ratios (up to 90%), without correspondence search. Validated on EuRoC Machine Hall simulations (axis-consistent) and ETH Hand-Eye benchmark (axis-ambiguous).
AI.conclusion: The proposed correspondence-free rotation alignment approach with TBV decomposition and PASI wrapper achieves linear complexity, high accuracy, robustness to outliers, and handles axis ambiguity effectively, making it practical for real-world calibration and registration tasks.

title: REM: Evaluating LLM Embodied Spatial Reasoning through Multi-Frame Trajectories
summary: Humans build viewpoint-independent cognitive maps through navigation, enabling intuitive reasoning about object permanence and spatial relations. We argue that multimodal large language models (MLLMs), despite extensive video training, lack this fundamental spatial reasoning capability, a critical limitation for embodied applications. To demonstrate these limitations and drive research, we introduce REM (Reasoning over Embodied Multi-Frame Trajectories), a benchmark using controllable 3D environments for long-horizon embodied spatial reasoning. REM systematically evaluates key aspects like object permanence/distinction, spatial relationships, and numerical tracking across dynamic embodied viewpoints. Our evaluation shows that the best-performing current models exhibit promising overall performance, but become increasingly unreliable at even moderate complexity levels easily handled by humans. These findings highlight challenges MLLMs face in developing robust spatial representations from sequential visual input. Consequently, REM provides targeted metrics and diagnostics to foster improved spatial understanding in future models.

AI.tldr: REM benchmark reveals MLLMs' fundamental limitations in embodied spatial reasoning compared to humans' viewpoint-independent cognitive maps, despite extensive video training.
AI.motivation: Humans develop viewpoint-independent cognitive maps through navigation, enabling intuitive spatial reasoning about object permanence and relations. MLLMs lack this fundamental capability despite extensive video training, creating critical limitations for embodied AI applications.
AI.method: Introduces REM (Reasoning over Embodied Multi-Frame Trajectories) benchmark using controllable 3D environments for long-horizon embodied spatial reasoning. Systematically evaluates object permanence/distinction, spatial relationships, and numerical tracking across dynamic embodied viewpoints.
AI.result: Best-performing current models show promising overall performance but become increasingly unreliable at moderate complexity levels easily handled by humans. Models struggle with developing robust spatial representations from sequential visual input.
AI.conclusion: REM provides targeted metrics and diagnostics to foster improved spatial understanding in future models, addressing fundamental limitations in MLLMs' spatial reasoning capabilities for embodied applications.

title: Sign Language Recognition using Bidirectional Reservoir Computing
summary: Sign language recognition (SLR) facilitates communication between deaf and hearing individuals. Deep learning is widely used to develop SLR-based systems; however, it is computationally intensive and requires substantial computational resources, making it unsuitable for resource-constrained devices. To address this, we propose an efficient sign language recognition system using MediaPipe and an echo state network (ESN)-based bidirectional reservoir computing (BRC) architecture. MediaPipe extracts hand joint coordinates, which serve as inputs to the ESN-based BRC architecture. The BRC processes these features in both forward and backward directions, efficiently capturing temporal dependencies. The resulting states of BRC are concatenated to form a robust representation for classification. We evaluated our method on the Word-Level American Sign Language (WLASL) video dataset, achieving a competitive accuracy of 57.71% and a significantly lower training time of only 9 seconds, in contrast to the 55 minutes and $38$ seconds required by the deep learning-based Bi-GRU approach. Consequently, the BRC-based SLR system is well-suited for edge devices.

AI.tldr: Proposed efficient sign language recognition system using MediaPipe for hand joint extraction and echo state network-based bidirectional reservoir computing for temporal processing, achieving competitive accuracy with dramatically reduced training time suitable for edge devices.
AI.motivation: Deep learning-based SLR systems are computationally intensive and require substantial resources, making them unsuitable for resource-constrained edge devices. There's a need for efficient SLR systems that can operate on devices with limited computational capabilities.
AI.method: Combines MediaPipe for extracting hand joint coordinates from sign language videos, then processes these features using an echo state network (ESN)-based bidirectional reservoir computing (BRC) architecture. BRC processes features in both forward and backward directions to capture temporal dependencies, with concatenated states forming robust representations for classification.
AI.result: Achieved 57.71% accuracy on WLASL dataset with only 9 seconds training time, compared to 55 minutes and 38 seconds for deep learning-based Bi-GRU approach. Demonstrates competitive performance with dramatically reduced computational requirements.
AI.conclusion: The BRC-based SLR system is efficient, computationally lightweight, and well-suited for deployment on edge devices, offering a practical solution for real-time sign language recognition in resource-constrained environments.

title: Med-CMR: A Fine-Grained Benchmark Integrating Visual Evidence and Clinical Logic for Medical Complex Multimodal Reasoning
summary: MLLMs MLLMs are beginning to appear in clinical workflows, but their ability to perform complex medical reasoning remains unclear. We present Med-CMR, a fine-grained Medical Complex Multimodal Reasoning benchmark. Med-CMR distinguishes from existing counterparts by three core features: 1) Systematic capability decomposition, splitting medical multimodal reasoning into fine-grained visual understanding and multi-step reasoning to enable targeted evaluation; 2) Challenging task design, with visual understanding across three key dimensions (small-object detection, fine-detail discrimination, spatial understanding) and reasoning covering four clinically relevant scenarios (temporal prediction, causal reasoning, long-tail generalization, multi-source integration); 3) Broad, high-quality data coverage, comprising 20,653 Visual Question Answering (VQA) pairs spanning 11 organ systems and 12 imaging modalities, validated via a rigorous two-stage (human expert + model-assisted) review to ensure clinical authenticity. We evaluate 18 state-of-the-art MLLMs with Med-CMR, revealing GPT-5 as the top-performing commercial model: 57.81 accuracy on multiple-choice questions (MCQs) and a 48.70 open-ended score, outperforming Gemini 2.5 Pro (49.87 MCQ accuracy, 45.98 open-ended score) and leading open-source model Qwen3-VL-235B-A22B (49.34 MCQ accuracy, 42.62 open-ended score). However, specialized medical MLLMs do not reliably outperform strong general models, and long-tail generalization emerges as the dominant failure mode. Med-CMR thus provides a stress test for visual-reasoning integration and rare-case robustness in medical MLLMs, and a rigorous yardstick for future clinical systems.

AI.tldr: Med-CMR is a fine-grained benchmark for evaluating medical multimodal reasoning in MLLMs, featuring systematic capability decomposition, challenging tasks, and broad clinical data coverage, revealing GPT-5 as top performer but highlighting limitations in specialized medical models and long-tail generalization.
AI.motivation: MLLMs are entering clinical workflows but their ability to perform complex medical reasoning remains unclear, necessitating a comprehensive benchmark to evaluate their medical multimodal reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: Created Med-CMR benchmark with three core features: 1) systematic capability decomposition into fine-grained visual understanding and multi-step reasoning, 2) challenging task design across visual dimensions and clinical scenarios, 3) broad high-quality data coverage with 20,653 VQA pairs validated via two-stage expert review.
AI.result: Evaluated 18 state-of-the-art MLLMs: GPT-5 performed best (57.81% MCQ accuracy, 48.70 open-ended score), outperforming Gemini 2.5 Pro and leading open-source models. Specialized medical MLLMs didn't reliably outperform general models, and long-tail generalization was the dominant failure mode.
AI.conclusion: Med-CMR provides a stress test for visual-reasoning integration and rare-case robustness in medical MLLMs, serving as a rigorous benchmark for future clinical AI systems while highlighting current limitations in specialized medical models and long-tail generalization.

title: Audio-Visual World Models: Towards Multisensory Imagination in Sight and Sound
summary: World models simulate environmental dynamics to enable agents to plan and reason about future states. While existing approaches have primarily focused on visual observations, real-world perception inherently involves multiple sensory modalities. Audio provides crucial spatial and temporal cues such as sound source localization and acoustic scene properties, yet its integration into world models remains largely unexplored. No prior work has formally defined what constitutes an audio-visual world model or how to jointly capture binaural spatial audio and visual dynamics under precise action control with task reward prediction. This work presents the first formal framework for Audio-Visual World Models (AVWM), formulating multimodal environment simulation as a partially observable Markov decision process with synchronized audio-visual observations, fine-grained actions, and task rewards. To address the lack of suitable training data, we construct AVW-4k, a dataset comprising 30 hours of binaural audio-visual trajectories with action annotations and reward signals across 76 indoor environments. We propose AV-CDiT, an Audio-Visual Conditional Diffusion Transformer with a novel modality expert architecture that balances visual and auditory learning, optimized through a three-stage training strategy for effective multimodal integration. Extensive experiments demonstrate that AV-CDiT achieves high-fidelity multimodal prediction across visual and auditory modalities with reward. Furthermore, we validate its practical utility in continuous audio-visual navigation tasks, where AVWM significantly enhances the agent's performance.

AI.tldr: First formal framework for Audio-Visual World Models (AVWM) that jointly captures binaural spatial audio and visual dynamics with action control and reward prediction, using a novel Audio-Visual Conditional Diffusion Transformer (AV-CDiT) and a new 30-hour dataset (AVW-4k).
AI.motivation: Existing world models focus primarily on visual observations, but real-world perception involves multiple sensory modalities. Audio provides crucial spatial and temporal cues (sound localization, acoustic properties) that are largely unexplored in world modeling. No prior work has formally defined audio-visual world models or how to jointly capture binaural audio and visual dynamics with precise action control and task rewards.
AI.method: 1) Formal framework for AVWM as partially observable Markov decision process with synchronized audio-visual observations, actions, and rewards. 2) Created AVW-4k dataset (30 hours, 76 indoor environments) with binaural audio-visual trajectories, action annotations, and reward signals. 3) Proposed AV-CDiT (Audio-Visual Conditional Diffusion Transformer) with modality expert architecture balancing visual/auditory learning, using three-stage training strategy for multimodal integration.
AI.result: AV-CDiT achieves high-fidelity multimodal prediction across visual and auditory modalities with reward. Validated in continuous audio-visual navigation tasks where AVWM significantly enhances agent performance compared to visual-only approaches.
AI.conclusion: This work establishes the first formal framework for audio-visual world models, demonstrating that integrating audio with visual information improves world modeling and enhances agent performance in multimodal tasks like navigation. The proposed AV-CDiT architecture and AVW-4k dataset enable effective joint learning of audio-visual dynamics.

title: FOM-Nav: Frontier-Object Maps for Object Goal Navigation
summary: This paper addresses the Object Goal Navigation problem, where a robot must efficiently find a target object in an unknown environment. Existing implicit memory-based methods struggle with long-term memory retention and planning, while explicit map-based approaches lack rich semantic information. To address these challenges, we propose FOM-Nav, a modular framework that enhances exploration efficiency through Frontier-Object Maps and vision-language models. Our Frontier-Object Maps are built online and jointly encode spatial frontiers and fine-grained object information. Using this representation, a vision-language model performs multimodal scene understanding and high-level goal prediction, which is executed by a low-level planner for efficient trajectory generation. To train FOM-Nav, we automatically construct large-scale navigation datasets from real-world scanned environments. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of our model design and constructed dataset. FOM-Nav achieves state-of-the-art performance on the MP3D and HM3D benchmarks, particularly in navigation efficiency metric SPL, and yields promising results on a real robot.

AI.tldr: FOM-Nav: A modular framework for Object Goal Navigation that combines Frontier-Object Maps with vision-language models to improve exploration efficiency and semantic understanding.
AI.motivation: Existing approaches have limitations: implicit memory methods struggle with long-term memory retention and planning, while explicit map-based methods lack rich semantic information. There's a need for a solution that combines efficient spatial exploration with fine-grained semantic understanding.
AI.method: Proposes FOM-Nav framework with Frontier-Object Maps that jointly encode spatial frontiers and fine-grained object information online. Uses vision-language models for multimodal scene understanding and high-level goal prediction, executed by a low-level planner for trajectory generation. Trained on automatically constructed large-scale navigation datasets from real-world scanned environments.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on MP3D and HM3D benchmarks, particularly in navigation efficiency metric SPL. Shows promising results on real robot deployment.
AI.conclusion: FOM-Nav effectively addresses Object Goal Navigation challenges by combining spatial exploration efficiency with semantic understanding through Frontier-Object Maps and vision-language models, demonstrating superior performance in both simulation and real-world settings.

title: Opening the Sim-to-Real Door for Humanoid Pixel-to-Action Policy Transfer
summary: Recent progress in GPU-accelerated, photorealistic simulation has opened a scalable data-generation path for robot learning, where massive physics and visual randomization allow policies to generalize beyond curated environments. Building on these advances, we develop a teacher-student-bootstrap learning framework for vision-based humanoid loco-manipulation, using articulated-object interaction as a representative high-difficulty benchmark.
